title: What is the relationship between mesmerism, hypnotism, and suggestion? How do they differ, and what are their similarities? An exploration of the history and theory of these related points of study.
first_phrase: In this last part of the text, Donato continues to discuss the topic of mesmerism, hypnosis, and suggestion with the doctors present. He presents his own system and classifications for these phenomena and challenges the doctors' theories on the subject. Donato also describes how innovators and those who challenge the norms are often accused of charlatanry, and gives examples of famous inventors who were once seen as mere artisans or uneducated. The text concludes with Donato demonstrating a strange new suggestion on Cornât, causing him to forget the number 2 and preventing him from opening his eyes. Donato's theories and demonstrations challenge the traditional views held by the doctors and add a new dimension to the discussion on mesmerism and suggestion.

Donato. — Messieurs, voici une suggestion aussi bizarre que nouvelle sur une personne évidemment éveillée, (A Cornât) Ouvre les yeux' Cornât. — Je ne puis. Donato. — Dors-tu? Cornât. — (riant) Pas plus que vous. Donato.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the texts presented here explore a range of topics including the effects of suggestion on memory and perception, the loss of an esteemed journalist, and the misconceptions surrounding magnetism and hypnosis. While some of these subjects may seem disparate, they all share an emphasis on empirical observation and a rejection of pseudo-scientific claims. Through careful study and analysis, we can gain a deeper understanding of the world around us and distinguish truth from falsehood.
